questions.question: What is a fundamental property of a wide-sense stationary (WSS) process?

answers.a: It has a zero mean and constant variance.
answers.b: Its autocorrelation depends only on the time difference.
answers.c: Its power spectral density is a constant value.
answers.d: Its mean is always equal to zero.

explanations.a: A WSS process can have a non-zero mean and varying variance.
explanations.b: The autocorrelation function of a WSS process depends only on the time difference.
explanations.c: The power spectral density of a WSS process is not constant but depends on the frequency.
explanations.d: A WSS process does not necessarily have a zero mean.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a Linear Time-Invariant (LTI) system?

answers.b: Time invariance ensures system response shifts with input shifts.
answers.c: The response to a sinusoidal input is always a sinusoid of the same frequency.
answers.d: The system must always be causal.

explanations.a: Superposition is a defining property of LTI systems.
explanations.b: Time invariance ensures the output shifts in response to input shifts.
explanations.c: Sinusoidal inputs produce sinusoidal outputs of the same frequency in LTI systems.
explanations.d: An LTI system can be non-causal, such as in certain mathematical models.

questions.question: The autocorrelation function of a WSS process is:

explanations.a: The autocorrelation function is symmetric for WSS processes.
explanations.b: Exponential decay is a possible form, but it is not a general property.
explanations.c: A triangular function is not a general property of WSS autocorrelation.
explanations.d: A delta function corresponds to white noise, not WSS signals.

questions.question: In the context of LTI systems, what does the convolution operation represent?

answers.a: The multiplication of two signals in the time domain.
answers.b: The multiplication of two signals in the frequency domain.
answers.c: The relationship between input, impulse response, and output.
answers.d: The inverse Fourier Transform of the power spectral density.

explanations.b: Convolution in the time domain corresponds to multiplication in the frequency domain.
explanations.c: Convolution relates the input, impulse response, and output of an LTI system.
explanations.d: The inverse Fourier transform is unrelated to convolution directly.

questions.question: What does the ARMA model represent in signal processing?

answers.a: A model for predicting deterministic signals.
answers.b: A combination of an autoregressive and moving average process.
answers.c: A strictly linear model for random signals.
answers.d: A method for measuring the noise power of a process.

explanations.a: ARMA models are used for stochastic processes, not deterministic signals.
explanations.b: ARMA combines autoregressive (AR) and moving average (MA) components.
explanations.c: ARMA models are not strictly linear but a combination of processes.
explanations.d: ARMA is not specifically a noise measurement method.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between an AR and MA process?

answers.a: An AR process depends on past noise values, while an MA process depends on past signal values.
answers.b: An AR process depends on past values of the signal, while an MA process depends on past noise values.
answers.c: An AR process has no memory, while an MA process has infinite memory.
answers.d: An AR process is deterministic, while an MA process is stochastic.

explanations.a: This reverses the roles of AR and MA processes.
explanations.b: AR uses past signal values, while MA uses past noise values.
explanations.c: Both AR and MA processes have finite memory in practice.
explanations.d: Both processes are stochastic, not deterministic.

questions.question: Which parameter is used to determine stationarity in a stochastic process?

explanations.a: WSS processes do have constant mean and variance, but this alone does not ensure stationarity.
explanations.b: Cross-correlation involves two signals, not a single process.
explanations.c: The autocorrelation function determines stationarity since it depends only on time difference for WSS processes.
explanations.d: Power spectral density is derived from the autocorrelation function.

questions.question: In an ARMA(1,1) model, what does the '1' in the AR part indicate?

answers.a: The model uses one noise term.
answers.b: The model uses one past signal value.
answers.c: The model has one autoregressive and one moving average parameter.
answers.d: The model uses one future signal value.

explanations.a: The AR component refers to past signal values, not noise terms.
explanations.b: The '1' in AR refers to the use of one past signal value.
explanations.c: This describes the overall ARMA model but not the specific AR part.
explanations.d: AR models do not use future signal values.

questions.question: How can the output of an LTI system be determined if the input signal is sinusoidal?

answers.a: By finding the convolution of the input signal with the system's impulse response.
answers.b: By adding the input to the system's impulse response.
answers.c: By multiplying the input frequency with the system's bandwidth.
answers.d: By integrating the input signal over time.

explanations.a: The convolution operation determines the output of an LTI system.
explanations.b: Adding the input to the impulse response is not correct.
explanations.c: Multiplying the frequency with the bandwidth is irrelevant.
explanations.d: Integration does not directly determine the LTI system's output.

questions.question: What does the term 'causal' mean in the context of ARMA models?

answers.a: The model depends only on present and past values.
answers.b: The model depends on future values.
answers.c: The model is stable and bounded.

explanations.a: Causal models depend only on present and past values.
explanations.b: Non-causal models depend on future values.
explanations.c: Stability is a separate concept from causality.
